I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans to 
Mongolia for the Support for COVID-19 Vaccine Delivery in Mongolia under the Asia Pacific 
Vaccine Access Facility.1 The project will benefit substantively from an abbreviated consideration 
period by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Board of Directors as it will expedite disbursement 
through retroactive financing of Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility (APVAX)-eligible coronavirus 
disease  (COVID-19)  vaccines.  The  government  is  negotiating  supply  contracts  with 
manufacturers of APVAX-eligible vaccines for immediate procurement.  
 
2.  The project is structured to provide the Government of Mongolia with immediate and 
flexible financing to purchase safe and effective vaccines against COVID-19 through APVAX. The 
rapid response component (RRC) will provide financing for direct procurement of APVAX-eligible 
vaccines  from  manufacturers  as  well  as  international  logistics  to  Mongolia.  The  Asian 
Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) will provide joint cofinancing to support the procurement of 
APVAX-eligible COVID-19 vaccines, in full alignment with the project outcome and ADB’s policies 
and procedures. 
 
3.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  operational  priorities  of  Strategy  2030:  
(i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, (ii) accelerating progress in gender 
equality, (iii) strengthening governance and institutional capacity, and (iv) fostering regional 
cooperation and integration.2 The project is consistent with the ADB country partnership strategy 
for Mongolia, 2017–20203 as well as the upcoming country partnership strategy for Mongolia, 
2021–2024 which aims to help the country recover from COVID-19 and lay resilient foundations 
for inclusive and sustainable growth.  
 
4.  Mongolia  has  met  the  criteria  required  for  accessing  APVAX  as  detailed  in  
Table 1. The government has (i) demonstrated an adverse impact of the COVID-19 pandemic,  
(ii) completed a needs assessment and a National Deployment and Vaccination Plan (NDVP),  
(iii) prepared an incremental medical waste management plan, (iv) organized direct contracting 
procurement  arrangements  in  line  with  ADB  guidelines,  (v) submitted  the  governor’s  letter 
confirming the government’s commitment to ensure compliance with the APVAX vaccine eligibility 
criteria, and (vi) established an effective development partner coordination mechanism.

II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
 
5.  Mongolia’s COVID-19 situation. COVID-19 was first detected in the People’s Republic 
of China in December 2019, prompting the Government of Mongolia to respond immediately to 
avoid rapid spread of the disease. The State Emergency Commission of Mongolia instituted strict 
emergency measures by mid-January 2020 that successfully prevented the spread of COVID-19

3 
in Mongolia, and launched the NDVP against COVID-19 on 11 January 2021.4 These measures 
included international and national travel restrictions; non-essential business closures; public 
awareness campaigns to prevent the spread of the virus; restrictions on public gatherings, 
meetings, and celebrations; the closure of schools; and the preparation of hospitals to deal with 
the expected surge in COVID-19 cases and the need for emergency care. The first case of 
community transmission was reported on 11 November 2020, leading to the detection of several 
clusters of local transmission in the capital city, Ulaanbaatar, and several aimags (provinces). The 
government immediately implemented three rounds of strict lockdowns from November 2020 to 
mid-April 2021, which helped reduce congestion in aimags and slow the spread of COVID-19 in 
Ulaanbaatar. As of 12 May 2021, the Ministry of Health (MOH) reported that of the total 46,448 
COVID-19 cases, most of the cases (40,830) were in Ulaanbaatar and other cases (5,618) were 
in aimags. About 81.2% (1,678,198) of the target population (18 years old and above) has 
received their first vaccine dose and 31.1% (631,666) has received their second vaccine dose.5 
The risk of continued community spread remains substantial, especially in Ulaanbaatar, which is 
the main national and international travel hub and home to half of Mongolia’s population of 3.3 
million. 
 
6.  Impact on Mongolia’s economy. The impact of the COVID-19 crisis has been more 
severe and prolonged on the Mongolian economy than initial expectations in 2020. Mongolia’s 
economy shrank by 5.3% in 2020, a drop of 10.5 percentage points compared with 2019. Official 
job losses reached 63,900 or 5.4% of total employment, and the unemployment rate increased 
by 1.0 percentage point to 7.6% in the second half of 2020. Export shocks led to a 9.4% 
contraction in the mining industry, mainly because of a decline in coal and crude oil output, 
dragging down growth by 1.9 percentage points. Except for agriculture, all sectors—including 
transportation, construction, trade, and services—shrank. The overall budget deficit increased 
significantly to 9.6% of gross domestic product in 2020 because of revenue shortfalls, fiscal 
response measures against COVID-19, and the contraction in gross domestic product. The 
banking industry experienced a credit crunch throughout 2020; and private companies, especially 
micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises that lacked access to credit, faced severe liquidity 
shortage issues. 
 
7.  Impact on poor and vulnerable groups. Although official poverty data for 2020 will be 
released in the second half of 2021, it is expected that COVID-19 will significantly increase the 
poverty rate from its level of 28.4% in 2018. This is anticipated given the structure of poverty in 
Mongolia, its historical experience, and the recent increase in job losses to 133,000 as of Q1 2021 
which is an 11.2% reduction in total jobs compared to Q4 2019. A further 27.3% of people live 
just above the poverty line and are vulnerable to falling into poverty because of shocks. Mongolia 
has a history of economic shocks causing large increases in poverty. After a collapse in the growth 
rate to 1.2% in 2016 poverty increased by 8 percentage points to 29.6% from 2014 levels. In 2009 
the poverty rate increased by 3.5 points to 38.7% within 12 months when GDP contracted sharply 
by 1.3%.6 A high proportion of people living in ger (Mongolian movable, circular traditional 
dwelling) areas with poor access to health, water, sanitation, and social services are particularly 
vulnerable to COVID-19. Many ger areas are in poor urban districts of cities that suffer from 
environmental vulnerability, underemployment, and underinvestment in basic infrastructure. The

Vaccination Plan against COVID-19. Order of the Chair of the State Emergency Commission. No. 5. Ulaanbaatar.

12 May 2021).

4 
poor in rural areas largely depend on herding livestock and farming as their main source of income 
and their nomadic lifestyle requires targeted vaccination plans. 
 
8.  Impact on gender. Women in Mongolia are disproportionally affected by the COVID-19 
pandemic as they comprise 82% of frontline health workers and have a higher risk of exposure, 
illness, and death. This is exacerbated by the increased burden of unpaid care work at home 
because of the national lockdowns as well as women’s jobs (such as service sector, tourism, and 
hospitality work) being more vulnerable to the impacts of COVID-19.7 In addition, the crisis has 
had an adverse impact on gender-based violence, as the number of hotline calls and women 
resorting to shelters has increased significantly since the start of the pandemic.8 Misinformation 
regarding the effects of vaccines on fertility may increase hesitancy among the female population 
of childbearing age, affecting the expected outcome of reaching herd immunity. 
 
9.  Impact on the health system. Mongolia’s health sector has made significant progress in 
improving health outcomes in recent years. The average life expectancy at birth increased to 
70 years in 2018, up from 69 years in 2016.9 Mongolia achieved its Millennium Development Goal 
targets in 2015 for maternal and child mortality. These hard-earned gains are under threat 
because of the enormous pressure the COVID-19 pandemic is placing on the country’s health 
care  system.  As  of  12  May  2021,  2,800,505  polymerase  chain  reaction  tests  have  been 
conducted; 10,531 patients have been hospitalized; and 73,589 people have undergone strict 
quarantine under medical observation (footnote 5). The increasing number of people hospitalized 
because of COVID-19 draws precious health resources away from the treatment of other serious 
illnesses such as heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and cancer, which are the leading causes of 
death in Mongolia. The health system’s limited human and fiscal resources are being used for 
testing, extra remuneration for frontline health care workers and other relevant government 
workers, and preparations for the surge in COVID-19 infections and hospitalizations, including 
expensive intensive care capacities. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported that as of September 
2020,  the  government  had  allocated  an  additional  MNT850.0  billion  for  COVID-19-related 
expenses, including MNT18.3 billion for the health sector.10 As a whole, health sector expenditure 
increased by 26% in 2020 compared with 2019. These negative impacts make the rapid rollout of 
safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines a vital tool that will help Mongolia stop the pandemic. 
 
10.  COVID-19 National Deployment and Vaccination Plan. The NDVP11 is an integral part 
of Mongolia's overall national COVID-19 pandemic prevention and response strategic plan.12 It is 
based on the country’s readiness assessment, utilizing the Vaccine Introduction Readiness 
Assessment  Tool  (VIRAT)  and  the  Vaccine  Readiness  Assessment  Framework  (VRAF)

average of 247 minutes on unpaid household work, 2.2 times more than male respondents. ADB. Mongolia: Rapid

5 
developed  with  international  partners,  including  ADB,  the  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund 
(UNICEF),  the  World  Health  Organization  (WHO),  the  World  Bank,  and  other  government 
organizations involved in the vaccination program.13 WHO has validated the NDVP, which is a 
living  document that can  adapt  to changes  in  the vaccine type,  availability, target  groups, 
manufacturer’s instructions, and epidemiological situation. The NDVP aims to initially vaccinate 
20% of the population (about 692,342 people), focusing on high risk groups such as frontline 
health care workers, government workers deployed for the COVID-19 response, and adults aged 
50 and older. This approach is aligned with recommendations from the WHO Strategic Advisory 
Group of Experts on Immunization.14 By initially prioritizing these groups, the vaccination program 
will achieve its impact in reducing the consequences of the pandemic even in conditions of supply 
constraint. When subsequent consignments of the vaccine become available, up to a total of 60% 
of the population or all the adult population will be vaccinated. The prioritization of target groups 
is based on the health risks of the groups regardless of their tribal, urban, rural, and pastoral 
residential identities or the degrees of vulnerability. The NDVP ultimately aims to vaccinate 60% 
of the population free of charge.

11.  National  Deployment  and  Vaccination  Plan  implementation.  Distribution  of  the 
COVID-19 vaccine builds upon the supply chain for routine immunization following the national 
guidelines  on  the  storage,  transportation,  and  dissemination  of  vaccines  and  biological 
preparations.15 However, additional refrigerators and cold chain equipment will be provided to 
each immunization unit to store the COVID-19 vaccines. Gaps in cold chain storage capacity for 
COVID-19 vaccines, especially for ultra-cold chain of –70ºC and dry-ice production, will be

addressed through projects supported by the World Bank16 and the Government of Japan.17 
Development assistance from ADB, the World Bank, the Government of Japan, UNICEF, and 
WHO  are  harmonized  through  complementary  activities  aiming  to  implement  the  NDVP. 
Vaccination is carried out at the permanent units of the National Center for Communicable 
Diseases, tertiary hospitals, district hospitals, district health centers, soum (subunit of an aimag) 
health centers in rural provinces, and family health centers. Most of the target population—
including adults aged 50 and above, people with disabilities, and vulnerable people—will be 
vaccinated using a fixed strategy (facility-based approach) at the nearest health facility where 
they live to ensure that they receive proper care and emergency medical assistance in case of 
adverse  events  following  immunization.  Multidisciplinary  personnel  deployed  in  national  
COVID-19 response measures are given vaccines using an outreach vaccination strategy in 
temporary  immunization  units.  A  mobile  vaccination  team  is  used  to  cover  hard-to-reach 
populations  who  reside  in  remote  areas.  Out  of  the  planned  548 immunization  units,  50 
permanent immunization units have been established in Ulaanbaatar City, where vaccination 
against COVID-19 began on 23 February 2021. The government carried out a comprehensive 
mapping of all available human resources, including additional staff from the Red Cross, retired 
staff, and preschool health staff; and developed a detailed list of health workers who will be 
mobilized in the vaccination process, with an assigned role for each worker. Staff training has 
been planned and will be carried out in phases, covering about 21,000 health care workers and 
17,000 non-health sector workers, including social mobilizers, journalists, and volunteers.  
 
12.  Joint working groups have been established to monitor the preparation of temporary and 
permanent immunization units and vaccine quality, safety, transportation, and storage on site 
during the immunization process.18 In addition, the General Agency for Specialized Inspection 
carries out external monitoring of the vaccination process and reports directly to the State 
Emergency Commission. Grievance mechanisms have been established at the General Agency 
for Specialized Inspection, the Ulaanbaatar City Department of Health, and the MOH. The 
government has developed a unified electronic immunization registry of COVID-19 vaccination 
record  with  people’s  vital  information  for  daily  analysis  and  reporting.  An  effective  risk 
communication plan has been prepared and implemented.19 This includes a comprehensive set 
of actions, such as developing information, communication, and training materials for health care 
workers  and  the  general  population;  training  social  mobilizers  and  influencers  to  provide 
information to the public on COVID-19 vaccination; and conducting active surveillance of the 
public attitude during and after vaccination. 
 
13.  Medical waste management. An increase in medical waste (e.g., syringes, vials, and 
personal protective equipment from vaccinators) is anticipated for national COVID-19 vaccine 
deployment. Medical waste management is carried out following standard procedures approved

14.  Financing needs. Based on the results of the VIRAT and VRAF, the Government of 
Mongolia estimated an indicative financing need for NDVP implementation of $68.5 million–
$114.0 million, depending on the unit price of vaccines.24 The World Bank and the Government 
of Japan (footnotes 16 and 17) have committed a total of $72.2 million, of which $34.5 million is 
for vaccines. The World Bank and the Government of Japan planned to purchase vaccines 
through the COVID-19 Vaccines Global Access (COVAX) and UNICEF at a price of $7.00 per 
dose. However, according to the current COVID-19 vaccine market dashboard, the unit price for 
a  single  dose  of  vaccine  is  much  higher,  ranging  from  $2.06  to  $40.00. 25 Therefore,  the 
government revised its estimated financing needs to $114.0 million based on the approximate 
average of the COVID-19 vaccines within a higher range of prices ($15.00–$19.50) or $17.00 per 
dose.26 Given the delays and limited access to vaccines through COVAX, the Government of 
Mongolia has requested ADB and AIIB’s assistance to finance the purchase of vaccines through 
bilateral agreements. Vaccinating 60% of the population of Mongolia would require 4,549,676 
doses of vaccines.27 As of 12 May 2021, the government has managed to secure 2,934,940 
doses—sufficient to cover 82% of the target population.28

16.  ADB  support  for  Mongolia’s  health  sector  and  engagement  in  the  COVID-19 
response and vaccination. The Government of Mongolia and ADB have a long and important

19 technical assistance projects in Mongolia’s health sector. The government has requested ADB 
to provide support for a rapid response to COVID-19 because of ADB’s significant and impactful 
engagement in the health sector. ADB has responded to Mongolia’s immediate needs for medical

$400,000 to address and prevent domestic violence during the COVID-19 crisis through the 
provision of personal protective equipment and medical equipment for shelters and one-stop 
service centers enhancing access to emergency services during the crisis.30 
 
17.  Access criteria for the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility. Mongolia fulfills the 
criteria for accessing the APVAX resource envelope: (i) clear adverse socioeconomic impacts of 
the pandemic in Mongolia, as shown by robust economic analysis; (ii) a needs assessment 
conducted with support from UNICEF and WHO, using the internationally accepted VIRAT and 
VRAF assessments that served as a basis for the comprehensive national COVID-19 vaccination 
strategy and plan, which prioritizes the vaccination of high risk and vulnerable groups of the 
population,  and  reflects  the  management  of  incremental  medical  waste  and  procurement 
arrangements; and (iii) strong leadership and coordinated actions led by the government in 
implementing the national COVID-19 response and the vaccination strategy and plan, including 
the establishment of effective development partner coordination mechanisms. The government 
has secured Mongolia’s participation in COVAX AMC and is coordinating its efforts with ADB, 
UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank. To facilitate rapid procurement, the government plans to 
utilize  retroactive  financing  and/or  advance  contracting  to  speedily  secure  APVAX-eligible 
vaccines (Table 5). 
 
18.  To rapidly access COVID-19 vaccines amid severely constrained global supplies, the 
government  intends  to  purchase  COVID-19  vaccines  directly  from  manufacturers.  The 
government has mandated that national (domestic) vaccine authorization or approval for use will 
rely on the emergency use listing by WHO for approving COVID-19 vaccines or approval by a

B.  Project Description 
 
19.  Impact and outcome. The Government of Mongolia officially requested ADB’s financial 
support for securing safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines for the people of Mongolia.34 The 
primary objective of the project is to increase the availability of the APVAX-eligible vaccines for 
the priority population, as defined by the government in its NDVP. The project will be aligned with 
the RRC component of APVAX, including the list of eligible items and agreed list of eligible 
expenditures. The project supports with the following impact: morbidity and mortality of severe 
acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 reduced.35 The project will have the following outcome: 
priority population vaccinated against COVID-19.36 The project will support the implementation of 
the NDVP and contribute to the government’s efforts to immunize at least 30% of the population, 
which represents priority groups. 
 
20.  Output. The output of the project will be COVID-19 vaccines for priority population are 
efficiently procured and delivered. The delivery of safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines that meet 
APVAX eligibility criteria, with AIIB cofinancing, will immunize at least 30% of the population. The 
project will cover eligible expenditure under the RRC pertaining to international transportation of 
the vaccines from the manufacturers to Mongolia.

21.   The APVAX project builds on ADB’s health system strengthening assistance to Mongolia 
and  responds  to  Mongolia’s  need to  address the  global  emergency  that  is  the  COVID-19 
pandemic. The project contributes to regional public goods37 through reduction of COVID-19 risks 
to neighboring countries to facilitate safer movement of goods and people and enhanced trade 
and investment. 
 
22.  The  government  will  utilize ADB  financing  for the  purchase  of  COVID-19  vaccines. 
Addressing essential vaccine rollout pillars will be covered by the government with financial and 
technical support from the World Bank, WHO, UNICEF, and the proposed ADB-administered

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
26.  The MOH will be the executing agency for the project, supervised by the State Emergency 
Commission (footnote 4). The MOH will provide technical support for the implementation of the 
NDVP through the  National  Coordination  Committee,  which  includes  development  partners 
providing  COVID-19  support.  The  executing  agency  and  these  mechanisms  will  ensure 
coordination of the project with ADB and other development partners. Vaccines will be purchased 
through direct procurement from the manufacturer of APVAX-eligible COVID-19 vaccines to 
speedily  procure  vaccines  and  avoid  forecast  delays  in  procurement  through  COVAX  and 
UNICEF because of the severely restricted global supply of vaccines. To strengthen project 
readiness and avoid parallel project implementation arrangements, the project implementation 
unit (PIU) responsible for the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Health Sector Development projects will be 
responsible for the implementation of this project.41 The implementation period will be from 
June 2021 to December 2023. Implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 5 and 
described in detail in the PAM. The procurement of ADB-eligible vaccines will follow the APVAX 
policy requirements. Value for money will be achieved by securing multiple types of APVAX-
eligible vaccines on reasonable commercial terms and through close monitoring of contract 
implementation to ensure timely delivery. Retroactive financing arrangements are expected to be 
utilized after loan effectiveness for procurement of vaccines.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial Viability 
   
27.  In Mongolia, COVID-19 has negatively impacted economic activity, including declines in 
domestic  consumption,  production,  investment,  trade,  and  tourism,  largely  because  of  the 
stringent containment measures introduced both locally and globally. If allowed to continue, 
COVID-19 will, in the short term, overwhelm the existing health system, which will be unable to 
cope with the simultaneous burden of treatment of noncommunicable diseases such as heart 
disease, stroke, and cancer, in addition to COVID-19. This will lead to highly negative effects on 
human capital development. The immunization of 60% of the population will help achieve herd 
immunity, save lives, allow the resumption of economic activities, promote trade, and build human 
capital. Project outputs are public goods with no opportunity for cost recovery, so no financial 
viability assessment is required. The government has estimated an indicative financing need for 
NDVP implementation through the VIRAT and VRAF assessments and has conducted mapping 
of funding sources.42 
 
B.  Governance 
 
28.  Based  on  the  financial  management  assessments  of  the  MOH  and  subsequent 
assessments  carried  out  under  the  current  project,  the  MOH  has  adequate  accounting 
professionals as well as computerized financial accounting and reporting systems. Procedures 
on the flow of accounting, financial, and project physical progress related to the current project 
activities are available. All the agencies have clearly defined responsibilities, with accountability 
assigned  to  different  units  at  different  levels  of  authority.  The  MOF  will  oversee  financial 
management, including internal audits and performance audits, of the NDVP following national 
laws and regulations. The MOH will oversee the management of transport, storage, and security 
of vaccines, following national vaccination program guidelines. 
 
29.  The Mongolia National Audit Office will arrange annual audits for the project. The financial 
management assessments concluded that the financial management systems in the MOH meet 
government requirements in terms of staffing, accounting, and internal control. The PIU staff will 
 
42 Vaccine Needs Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

13 
implement the project in compliance with ADB’s policy, operation, and procedural requirements. 
The assessed pre-mitigation financial management risk is moderate. 
 
30.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  MOH.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 38). 
 
C.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
31.  Poverty and social. The project will improve emergency preparedness during epidemics 
and pandemics, and health workers’ safety in hospitals in Mongolia. It will directly benefit people 
who are at high risk of death from COVID-19 infection, and about 200,000 frontline workers, 
especially those with professions that put them at occupational risk because of the COVID-19 
pandemic. In addition, people with disabilities, people who suffer from chronic diseases, and 
vulnerable groups requiring social assistance will benefit from the vaccine rollout (Table 2). 
 
32.  Gender. The project is classified some gender elements. Vaccination with safe and 
effective COVID-19 vaccines will reduce illness and deaths among women. Priority groups for 
vaccination  under the  NDVP  include  health care  workers  (82%  of  whom  are  women)  and 
educators (96% of all teachers and workers at preschool education establishments, and 81.2% 
of  basic  teachers  from  the  general  secondary  schools  in  Mongolia,  are  women).  Further, 
operations staff working in 35 shelters and one-stop service centers, which provide a safe haven 
for victims of domestic violence, will be included as part of the prioritized population under the 
project, ensuring accessibility to such services during the crisis. Data generated through the 
implementation of the NDVP will be disaggregated by sex, priority group, and occupation for more 
effective targeting of vulnerable groups. Vaccination of the priority population will help reduce the 
burden of women’s unpaid and domestic work resulting from lockdowns, and help reduce gender-
based violence at home, which has spiked during the pandemic. Proposed complementary ADB-
administered JFPR grant assistance to Mongolia for supporting vaccine delivery systems and 
capacity building will target women for awareness raising, capacity building, and training for 
COVID-19 vaccine administration (footnote 23). 
 
D.  Safeguards 
 
33.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows.43 
 
34.  Environment (category C). The project will procure supplies but will not entail any civil 
works or activities that may cause major adverse impacts on the environment. Under the Fifth 
Health Sector Development Project (footnote 21), medical waste management capacity has 
increased, which will contribute to medical waste management for COVID-19 vaccines. The 
project will follow national regulations on medical waste. Due diligence assessments conducted 
by ADB on medical waste management systems found them to be largely adequate, with some 
gaps in capacity in aimags and soums, particularly in rural areas (footnote 22). These gaps will 
be filled by (i) the procurement of autoclaves under the World Bank COVID-19 emergency project 
(footnote 16); (ii) training for health workers on medical waste management and occupational 
health  and safety  under the  proposed JFPR  grant  linked  to the  project  (footnote  23);  and 
(iii) monitoring of medical waste, which is also supported through the proposed JFPR grant. 
 
 
43 ADB. Safeguard Categories.

14 
35.  Involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  (category  C).  The  project 
components will not involve civil works and will not trigger any land acquisition or involuntary 
resettlement impacts. The project will not cause adverse or differential impacts on ethnic groups, 
and they will benefit equally from the proposed vaccination of the priority population. 
 
E.  Procurement 
 
36.  The procurement of goods, works, and services will be carried out in a manner consistent 
with simplified and expedient procedures permitted under the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and as permitted under APVAX. Since the project will be financed 
under  APVAX,  ADB  member  country  eligibility  restrictions  will  be  waived  and  universal 
procurement will apply. ADB will be the lead cofinancier and partially administer the AIIB loan, 
ADB Procurement Policy will apply to all procurement. All procurement packages will be jointly 
financed by ADB and AIIB. To expedite procurement, both vaccines and international logistics will 
be procured using the direct contracting method. Vaccines will be purchased through bilateral 
agreements with manufacturers of APVAX-eligible COVID-19 vaccines. The government will be 
responsible for arranging the transport of the vaccines from the countries of origin to Mongolia. 
 
37.  A procurement risk assessment was carried out for the project and rated the procurement 
risk high. While the MOH has worked with ADB for many years and has implemented several 
ADB-financed projects, instances of noncompliance have occurred, including mis-procurement. 
In addition, the COVID-19 vaccine supply market is severely constrained, with few manufacturers, 
while the demand is extremely high. To mitigate these risks, (i) the government should identify 
multiple sources of vaccine supply to spread risk; (ii) all direct procurements to be funded by ADB 
and AIIB (including candidate contracts for retroactive financing) will be subject to ADB prior 
review; (iii) an existing PIU familiar with ADB procurement rules and procedures will be used for 
this project; and (iv) a vaccine procurement expert will be hired to assist the MOH in procurement, 
contract negotiation, and implementation. 
 
38.  Value for money in procurement will be achieved by (i) selecting candidate vaccines that 
are eligible for APVAX and best suited to the domestic logistics supply chain and distribution 
facilities;  (ii)  engaging  with manufacturers that  have  advantageous vaccine  availability  and 
delivery  timelines;  and  (iii)  entering  into  agreements  with  terms  and  conditions  that  are 
reasonable, bearing in mind the currently constrained market for COVID-19 vaccines worldwide.

b  ADB. Mongolia: Improving Access to Health Services for Disadvantaged Groups Investment Program. 
Source: ADB. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
40.  The Government of Mongolia and MOH have assured ADB that implementation of the 
project  shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  requirements,  including  those  concerning 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  financial 
management, and disbursement as described in detail in the project administration manual and 
loan  documents.  The  government  continues  to  coordinate  with  international  development 
partners  on  COVID-19  support  to  Mongolia  through  donor  coordination  mechanisms.  The 
government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the 
draft loan agreements. 
 
41.  No withdrawals shall be made from the loan accounts of both ADB and AIIB for financing 
eligible vaccines until: (i) ADB has received a letter from the government confirming (a) which 
COVID-19 vaccine(s) have been selected to be procured using the proceeds of the loans; 
(b) which of the eligibility criteria under APVAX have been satisfied in respect of the selected 
vaccines  to  be  procured;  and  (c)  such  COVID-19  vaccine(s)  have  received  all  necessary 
authorizations of the government, and have been authorized by the Human Medicine Council of 
Mongolia and any other relevant regulatory authorities for distribution and administration within 
the territory of the borrower; and (ii) based on the information provided in the aforementioned 
letter, ADB has notified the borrower that the COVID-19 vaccine(s) to be procured are designated 
as eligible vaccines under APVAX criteria.

16 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
42.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve: 
(i)  the loan of $9,500,000 to Mongolia for the Support for COVID-19 Vaccine Delivery 
in Mongolia under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility, from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources, in regular terms, with interest to be determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term 
of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years; and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
agreement presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the loan of $9,500,000 to Mongolia for the Support for COVID-19 Vaccine Delivery 
in Mongolia under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility, from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources, in concessional terms, with an interest charge at the rate of 2% 
per year during the grace period and thereafter; for a term of 25 years, including a 
grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially 
in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board. 
 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa 
President 
 
21 May 2021

metadata.Subject:
The project is structured to provide the Government of Mongolia with immediate and flexible financing to purchase safe and effective vaccines against COVID-19 through APVAX. The rapid response component (RRC) will provide financing for direct procurement of APVAX-eligible vaccines from manufacturers as well as international logistics to Mongolia.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated May 2021 is provided for the ADB project 55007-001 in Mongolia.
metadata.Title: Support for COVID-19 Vaccine Delivery in Mongolia under the Asia Pacific Vaccine Access Facility: Report and Recommendation of the President
